comment.author: 25100796@N08
comment._content: The caption says "Aspirantes".  I believe that term is used in Spanish to describe officer cadets (i.e., they are "aspiring" to officer status).  The Prussian style uniforms - not the norm for run of the mill soldiers - are also an indicator that these folks may be a bit more special than the term "recruit" conveys.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: There's a photo in the Getty Research Institute Digital Collections, called: Arcos de Belem (Avenue), aspirantes de Tlalpan archives.getty.edu/view/action/nmets.do?DOCCHOICE=5480437... taken by the Ten Tragic Days, between 9-18, February 1913. Where you can see the collumns arround the trees, and they seem to be the same style. If they are the same, then these aspirants, which by the Prussian style uniforms, could be officers that were photographed for the occasion of the centennial on Septembern, 1910 [for example, call nr. aproximates to ficture call number of this collection 2223-6 which was taken to Porfirio Díaz in september 1910 during the festivities for the centenial) standing in the south or north sides of the arsenal (Fabrica Nacional de Armas) or Ciudadela. Although, there's a picture printed in The Sun, issue February 23, 1913 (The Library of Congress, Chronicling America) chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030272/1913-02-23/ed-... where the cadets appear on Prussian style uniform, entitled TLALPAN CADETS WHO STARTED THE REVOLUTION. And seems that the picture was taken at the same spot. Dr. Roberto Duarte Plastic Surgeon
